thesis.description: When "Imprisonment in Greece" was suggested as the topic of this dissertation, it was not welcomed with great enthusiasm on my part; for not onlydid it seem a strange subject of research for a woman, but I had never given any particular thought to imprisonment in ancient Greece or anywhereelse. In the course of my research, however, I have found that the subject 1s one of absorbing interest and one well worth investigation; hence itis most surprising that no works have been written about it in modern times. This, nevertheless, is the case. [...]

thesis.description: Of recent years, following the elucidation of the constitution and structure of the more common mono and d1~aooharides, the attention of oarbohydrate ohemistshas been focussed more and more strongly on the higher polysaccharides. For example, among the plant polysaccharides, it has been definitelyestablished that cellulose and starch are long linear chains of anhydroglucose units. In the case of inulin and levan, the chain 1s made up ofanhydro-fructose units, while xylan and other pentosans are linear anhydro-pentose polymers. [...]

thesis.description: 1. The synthesis of tosyl esters from tosyl chloride has been extended to certain aryl-alkyl primary alcohols.2. Sodium iodide in acetone solution at room temperature replaces the tosyl groups in the toayl esters from arylalkyl primary alcohols with iodine,and with the same ease as with tosyl esters from primary alkyl alcohols.3. With secondary alkyl tosyl esters, replacement of the tosyl group by iodine takes place to a much smaller extent under the same experimentalconditions, namely, at room temperature.4. Interaction of sodium iodide and the tosyl esters of alk-aryl secondary alcohols, for example, benzhydrol, proceeds abnormally. In the case ofbenzhydrol, the reaction product is dibenzhydryl ether.5. Freudenbergts conclusions, that tertiary alcohols do not readily yield tosyl esters, have been confirmed.6. An account of the relative merits of the procedures for synthesizing tosyl esters has been given. [...]

thesis.description: Experimental graphology originated in France. Michon(1806-1881), turning away from the mere impressionistic interpretations of his predecessors,collected a vast number of handwriting specimens due to the pen of well-known personages, and comparing those scripts with the character traits ofthe writers, he evolved his famous "theory of signs", which is still prevalent in popular books on graphology. To a definite sign corresponds adefinite quality, and the absence of the sign betokens the absence of the quality. [...]

thesis.description: It was some 38 years ago that Sir William Crookes, eminent British scientist, in the first edition of his book, ""The Wheat Problem" predicted theinevitability of a long-run increase in the price of wheat. This grim prospect arose, he contended, due to the rapidlY diminishing supply ofavailable wheat land, which, according to him, would soon be inadequate to provide for the world's needs. Within an appreciable distance, hepredicted a scarcity of this vital foodstuff. [...]

thesis.description: This paper is a consideration of the animal communities found in two fresh-water ponds. It is an attempt to classify the members of the associationsand to determine their relations to their environment and to one another. A comparison of the two ponds will also be made. [...]

thesis.description: Agriculture was tl1e basis of the economic structure of Canada from 1763 to 1783. During this period the habitants increased the amount of landunder cultivation and also the agricultural production, growing more wheat and keeping more livestock. A good market for these commodities placedthe habitant in a sound economic position. He must have been better fed and better housed than he had previously been. At the same time Britishimmigrants enriched themselves by trade in wheat, lumber, fish, oil, and furs, and at Montreal there grew up a community of substantial merchants.Undoubtedly the first two decades of British rule were ones of economic development. [...]

Canada -- Economic conditions -- 1763-1867.

thesis.description: The importance of a clearer insight into the cellulose-water relationship can hardly be overemphasized. Aside from its value as a purely theoreticalconsideration in the realm of colloidal chemistry, a knowledge of the under-lying mechanism is greatly to be desired because the phenomena involvedaxe fundamental to the art of paper-making. It is undoubtedly the use of cellulosic materials in the latter connection that has supplied the greatestimpetus to research in this direction. It would therefore not be amiss to introduce a discussion of the cellulose-water relationship with anindication of its role in the making of paper (1) as it involves fundamental concepts of theoretical interest. [...]

thesis.title: The measurement of the dielectric constant of cellulose and that of adsorbed water vapour.

thesis.description: "Less than All cannot satisfy a man" 1s perhaps one of Blake's profoundest sayings, and it might well be taken as the motto of the great mystics,who were not to be satisfied with less than "all" , defined by them as God, and who claim to have found, in union with Him, profound and perfectsatisfaction. The heights of mysticism, however, have been attained by few, at least, few have been able to leave to the world the record of theirexperiences, though doubtless there have been, and are today, many inarticulate ones., mute but not inglorious, who showed and show forth in theirlives the transforming power of spiritual assurance. Mysticism is not, of course, found only in the Christian religion, but for purposes of thisstudy reference will be made (with the exception of one or two quotations) to its manifestation in that religion alone. [...]

thesis.subject: English Literature.
thesis.title: Studies of some English mystical poets in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

W. Dawson, David White, J. E. Hyde, A. o. Hayes, W. A. Bell, F. W. Gray,and others have contributed their valuable aid to the consideration of the many problems which confront one who attempts to analyze the geologichistory of the Sydney coal measures. [...]

thesis.description: 1. Satark effect in the HD spectrum has been observed under high dispersion between the wavelengths 4860 and 6400 1.0.2. The Stark effect in 70 lines of the Fulcher bands of RD have been meaBured. Displacement. in 27 unclassified line. are &120 reported as are also24 line undisplaced in the electric field.3. Stark effect manifests itself in this spectrum in th1is region by simple small displacements toward the red. In some instances two componentsoccur, but more have not been detected.4. The effect is 1n general irregular. Both 1nitial and final states seem to be influenced by the field.5. the d1aplacemente are for the most part quadratic in the field and no evidence of a linear Stark effect in HD baa been found.6. The present observations greatly extend the range of the only previous worker. Where they oyerlap the superior dispersion of the opticalapparatuus·used in this research assits in eliminating many uncertainties in the previous results.

thesis.description: The thermal decompositions of ethyl and normal propyl nitrite were investigated over a range of reduced pressures. The results, together with thosefor the other members of the nitrite series, are discussed from the point of view of the Kassel theory. Attention is focussed particularly on theeffect of increasing molecular complexity as one ascends an homologous series, since the nitrites form an ideal series for such a discussion.The Kassel theory apparently furnishes a complete explanation of the facts insofar as the effect of pressure on the rates is concerned. On theother hand, there is no satisfactory quantitative explanation for the increase in the high pressure rate with increasing molecular complexity.The factors which might contribute to such an increase are discussed, and it is concluded that the main factor is probably a progressivechange in binding energy as one ascends the homologous series.
thesis.creator: Katz, Sidney.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The effect of configuration on unimolecular reaction rates.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: From a study of the physiography of the Augmentation of Grenville it is concluded that large depressionslike the Pointe-au-Chene-Avoca depressionare the sites of former river courses. Rivers with conspicuous gorges like the Rouge river are pre-Glacial in age and diversion of thePointe-au-Chene-Avoca ancestral river into the Rouge river antedated glaciation by many thousands of years.The occurrence of benches in the east part of the Lachute map-area suggests a process of marine planation. Similar features exist in theAugmentation of Grenville. [...]

thesis.description: This thesis attempts to review the general characteristics of Byron's work and to estimate his influence not only in his own country hut in Europe.It discusses "briefly the place of Byron's theories, social, political and artistic, in our day, and tries to show that time has proved thewisdom of many of his ideas and principles.

thesis.description: Because of its close relationship to water and because of its wide use as an oxidizing agent the study of hydrogen peroxide is one of particularinterest. The properties of the peroxide and of its aqueous solutions have been under investigation in these laboratories for some time.The work to be described herein will deal quite fully with the electrical conductivity of nitric acid, and somewhat briefly with that of sulphuricacid in aqueous hydrogen peroxide. These electrolytes represent the strong, inorganic acids and will be compared with organic acids and inorganicsalts whose conductivity in aqueous peroxide has already been investigated.Such a study is also of interest from the viewpoint of the nitric acid. Almost no work has been done on its conductivity in any medium other thanwater. [...]
thesis.creator: MacLauchlan, Donald Wells.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The properties of hydrogen peroxide.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: An investigation of factors influencing seed transmission of viruses is presented.Evidence is given that the tobacco mosaic virus invades some ovules which as a result do not develop, while ovules which escape infection develop tomature seeds. The bean mosaic virus invades the embryo of the garden bean and is transmitted to the seedling.It has been determined that the phenomenon -of seed transmission of a virus cannot be explained on a basis of a continuity of plasmodesmata frommaternal to embryonic tissues. Such continuity was not found in either the bean which transmits the virus by seed or the tobacco which apparentlydoes not.Evidence is presented that the tobacco virus is not transmitted through pollen to the seed. Also pollen of diseased bean and tobacco plants wasfound non-infective.A hot-water treatment to free infected bean seed from mosaic virus is presented.
thesis.creator: McEvoy, Edward Thomas.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Seed transmission of plant viruses.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: As a preliminary to the historical part of this thesis, it is convenient to define the objective of the work, and enumerate the various *types* ofexperimental data which were to be obtained for this purpose.Broadly speaking, the main object in view was to obtain further information in regard to the physical chemical structure of cellulose and theinfluence of water adsorption and mercerization on this structure. Measurements previously carried out in this laboratory with this end in viewhave dealt with the isothermals of water and other vapours on cellulose (1, 2, 3, 4), with the densities (5), the alkali adsorption (6, 7), the heatconductivity (8), the dielectric constant (9, 10), the rates of adsorption (11) and the heats of wetting and water vapour adsorption (12) of suchsystems. [...]

thesis.description: The study entitled "Ndcroscopica1 Investigation of Certain Quebec Ores" , is divided into two parts. The present paper is part I, the "Technique ofInvestigation". The writer has attempted to present the technique of preparing opaque minerals for microscopical study and to discussthe methods used in their identification. It was thought advisable to give a brief history of the development of this subject and an outline of itsmore important applications, so that a perspective view of the position of mineralography within the geological sciences may be obtained.A few brief notes on the telluride minerals are given in chapter IV. [...]

thesis.subject: Geology.
thesis.title: Microscopical investigation of certain Quebec ores : pt.A. Technique of investigation.

thesis.description: 1. Stark effect in the spectrum of DQ has been observed under high dispersion in the spectral range 6500 - 5700 A at a field strength of 69 Kv/cm.2. Measurements of the Stark effect are reported for 173 lines of which 79 are classified Fulcher band lines, the remainder being as yetunclassified.3. The wave-lengths of the unclassified lines have been determined with an accuracy In most cases of better than 0.1 A.4. The Stark effect is of the same order of magnitude and of the same general nature as in H2. Most of the lines exhibit small simple displacements.In a number of cases two components are observed in each polarization.5. The theory of the Stark effect is discussed, and compared qualitatively with the experimental results.6. Partial agreement is found with the results of the only former observer whose investigation under low dispersion was restricted to the classifiedFulcher bands in this region.7. The Stark effect data for the unclassified lines should be of some value for their classification.

thesis.title: Stark effect in the molecular spectrum of deuterium.

thesis.description: The fur trade was for generations the chief industry of this continent. Tile struggles of France and Britain were not for possession of anapparently barren country. They were motivated by the desire to control the great wealth of the fur trade.UncLer the French regime the traffic was monopolistic in character. Colonizing companies possessing exclusive privileges forbade free trading,only to have their decrees flouted by Pierre Esprit Radisson and other members of that enterprising class known as coureurs des bois. [...]

thesis.description: Iron is found in plant tissues, particularly in those connected with photosynthesis, but very little is known of the role which it plays in plantmetabolism. That it is necessary for normal plant growth and wellbeing is evident from the chlorosis which develops in plants grown in soils ornutrient solutions deficient in iron. Although the iron is not present in the pigment itself, that it must be in some way related to it physiologicallywas emphasized by Moore (1), who assigned to iron some function in the photosynthesis of chlorophyll. [...]
thesis.creator: Parker, William Ernest.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Chemistry.
thesis.title: A study of the distribution of iron in plant tissue.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
